webTitle: Priyanka Chopra accused of 'encouraging nuclear war' with Pakistan

fields.headline: Priyanka Chopra accused of 'encouraging nuclear war' with Pakistan
fields.standfirst: Actor questioned at beauty conference about support for India’s armed forces amid tension between two countries
fields.trailText: Actor questioned at beauty conference about support for India’s armed forces amid tension between two countries
fields.body:
Priyanka Chopra has been accused of “encouraging nuclear war” over comments she made amid worsening tensions between India and Pakistan.

The Indian actor, who made her name in Bollywood before moving to the US, was confronted by an audience member at a cosmetics event in Los Angeles.

The woman, who named herself on Twitter as Ayesha Malik, was handed the microphone during the Q&A portion of a BeautyCon panel featuring Chopra.

In an exchange that was caught on camera, Malik said: “It was kind of hard hearing you talk about humanity, because as your neighbour, a Pakistani, I know you’re a bit of a hypocrite.”

Related: Priyanka Chopra: 'She was not going to be another pretty girl'

Malik cited a tweet sent by Chopra’s official account on 26 February in which the actress wrote “Jai Hind”, meaning “victory to India”.

Nuclear-equipped India and Pakistan are involved in a confrontation over the disputed region of Kashmir.

Malik added: “You are a Unicef ambassador for peace and you’re encouraging nuclear war against Pakistan. There’s no winner in this.

“As a Pakistani, millions of people like me have supported you in your business of Bollywood.”

Staff then grabbed the microphone away. Chopra, who is married to US pop star Nick Jonas, replied: “I hear you. Whenever you’re done venting. Got it? Done? Okay, cool.”

The 37-year-old said “war is not something that I’m really fond of, but I am patriotic”, adding “but I think that all of us have a sort of middle ground that we all have to walk”.

She added: “The way you came at me right now, girl, don’t yell. We’re all here for love. Don’t yell. Don’t embarrass yourself.

“Thank you for your enthusiasm and your question and your voice.”

Other celebrity speakers at BeautyCon 2019 include Ciara, Kelly Rowland and Tina Knowles.

webTitle: We’re a queer couple trying for a baby. Stop asking ‘How does that work?’ | Kat Patrick

fields.headline: We’re a queer couple trying for a baby. Stop asking ‘How does that work?’
fields.standfirst: These very intimate details of our lives are always requested as if nothing is at stake. It’s laziness masquerading as curiosity
fields.trailText: These very intimate details of our lives are always requested as if nothing is at stake. It’s laziness masquerading as curiosity
fields.body:
There are suddenly a lot of babies in my life. Lovely, squishy babies that are loud and ridiculous. Babies that squawk and dribble on pets, bibs and other babies. At mealtimes these babies smash already smashed food with their perfect, tiny fists and yet somehow I find them completely remarkable. I never thought I would be the sort of person who talks this much about babies, about starting a family, about parenting. But after a long, complicated road, my partner and I are happy to have finally decided: we do want kids, we really do.

But for us the choice to procreate has come with a caveat: when the subject of starting our family comes up, people contemplate mine and my partner’s bodies before asking “So how will that work?” There’s usually a brief pause as they remember their manners, following up with: “If you don’t mind me asking.”

Related: It’s a woman’s choice: falling fertility rates are not the business of government | Gaby Hinsliff

When we’re around people who know us only vaguely, at dinners and parties, it has become an inevitable conversation. They want to know about whether we will adopt, who wants to be pregnant, where the father will feature, if it’s publicly funded, and if not, how much it will cost. These intensely intimate details of our lives are always requested as if nothing is at stake; laziness masquerading as curiosity.

As a queer couple it can be overwhelming to start configuring the options, to ready yourself for the complicated, time-consuming process of having a baby. I understand that the question sometimes comes from a good-ish place. Asking about queer lifestyles could be seen as a demonstration of being a good ally, but also – it isn’t being a good ally. I think as a general rule, if you must contextualise something with “if you don’t mind me asking”, the person has probably already minded that you’re asking, but is now conversationally cornered, forced to reply no matter what, at risk of looking “rude” or “dramatic” if they don’t.

Asking about queer lifestyles could be seen as a demonstration of being a good ally, but also – it isn’t being a good ally

I don’t have many queries about how heterosexuality works because, despite not being cis or heterosexual, it was how I was taught to be in the world. All the information needed to get full marks in the cis-heterosexuality quiz is already everywhere, from romantic comedies to school curriculums, treated as if it is fact rather than my fiction.

I was raised in a sex education system that was still rooted in the reproductive emphasis of the 1950s; babies were a thing that happened at the end of a Taylor Swift-esque cis boy meets cis girl sort of love story. In fact, conceiving was made to seem so easy I spent the best part of my teens (read 20s) assuming you could get pregnant from a toilet seat. It’s important to add that I know too, from most of the parents who surround me, that no matter who you are, it can be a desperately private, often heartbreaking thing, trying to conceive. School didn’t prepare any of us for that, either.

Related: After a bruising year, the kindness of strangers made our wedding unforgettable | Kat Patrick

At school and afterwards, the idea of being a parent was something I had to gradually un-want, because it felt as though choosing to be queer was choosing not to have children. For me, realising that it’s OK to want a baby has been a painful, important unravelling. To really answer the question “How does that work?” I’d have to make myself entirely vulnerable. I don’t want to a lot of the time because crying in public is something I now like to do on my own terms, not everyone else’s.

Before baby-making, “How does that work?” was the same question I was asked about my sex life, by sticky cis boys at university who jammed their v-shaped fingers together, doomed to eternally confuse the amazing metrics of lesbian sex. It’s the same question I get asked about having to edge my double F chest into a binder whenever I leave the house, the same question a well-meaning friend put to me as she wondered about the grammatical confusion caused by “they” pronouns. In a world governed by heterosexual myths, it is strange when it is queerness that needs to be constantly justified.

It’s taken me half my queer life to unlearn the obligation of answering these questions. Instead, I will respond asking that they use Google, online forums, download PDFs and call for professional advice, as I’ve had to. I know that it’s OK to express my discomfort but for a long time, I felt as though I was defined by the way other people understood me. Now it’s a relief putting my own sense of self first.

• Kat Patrick is a journalist and author of children’s books

Comments on this piece will be premoderated

webTitle: #cheesedoff: how should Australia rename its food if the EU has its way?

fields.headline: #cheesedoff: how should Australia rename its food if the EU has its way?
fields.standfirst: Under a free trade deal, Australian producers may have to find new names for hundreds of products. Tell us what you think they should be called
fields.trailText: Under a free trade deal, Australian producers may have to find new names for hundreds of products. Tell us what you think they should be called
fields.body:
First they came for our champagne, now it’s our feta. Also gruyère, gorgonzola and scotch beef.

Under the terms of the free trade agreement being negotiated between Australia and the European Union, Australian producers may lose the right to name their products using terms the EU wants protected under a “geographical indictions” clause.

When France won the right to ring-fence champagne, so that it could only relate to sparkling wine produced from grapes grown in the Champagne region of France, it was not too hard simply to rename local products “sparkling wine”.

But what about feta? Should it be “tangy crumble bitch cheese” as @jules_lefevre suggested on Twitter? How to rename gruyère – “hard cheese good for gratin’”? And gorgonzola?

The EU’s list of proposed products whose names should be off limits includes hundreds of obscure beers, spirits, cheeses and meats – a veritable smorgasbord (or smorgyboard, as we may need to officially call it soon).

Tell us in the comments below how Australia should rename its products, or tweet your answer with the hashtag #cheesedoff.

webTitle: Ursula Yovich on giving up theatre: 'It wasn't making me happy any more'

fields.headline: Ursula Yovich on giving up theatre: 'It wasn't making me happy any more'
fields.standfirst: She just won a Helpmann for her performance in Barbara and the Camp Dogs, but the actor says stepping away from the stage is ‘part of growing up’
fields.trailText: She just won a Helpmann for her performance in Barbara and the Camp Dogs, but the actor says stepping away from the stage is ‘part of growing up’
fields.body:
“I’ve been struggling with depression for many, many years,” says Ursula Yovich. “One of the hard things about depression is: I would rather be at home in bed. But I have to get out and I have to perform and I have to put on a persona that has this energy I don’t have.”

Yovich is one of Australia’s most celebrated performers. Coming to theatre from her first love, singing, she is a generous actor, channelling emotion through her whole body. Her full-bodied voice fills a space. In moments of silence, in stories of great humour and stories of great tragedy, she is captivating. She crackles with passion and warmth. And she has decided to give up the stage.

In June, she announced her retirement. This week at Darwin festival, she will perform for the last time in The Man With the Iron Neck, a physical theatre piece she also wrote.

“After a while I just went: I cannot pretend I can actually do this any more,” she says.

Most of my career has been about mob. And there’s always trauma in that. Always

Ursula Yovich

At the close of 22 years, appearing with every major theatre company in Australia, Yovich tells Guardian Australia she is putting herself first. “It’s about me going away, and try and be healed, for me.”

Yovich grew up between Darwin and Maningrida in Arnhem Land. Her first language was her mother’s, Burarra. When she was eight her mother left, and Yovich and her siblings were raised in Darwin by a single father.

Her father fostered her love of performance, encouraging Yovich to attend an audition at Corrugated Iron Youth Arts. “I didn’t do a good job,” she laughs. “I was very shy.” She wasn’t cast. But when another girl dropped out, Yovich replaced her. “I’ve been on stage ever since.”

At 18, Yovich left for Perth to study in a one-year program for Aboriginal performers. She remembers a large warehouse in Northbridge, a lone piano and “a couple of church pews up against the wall. That was it.”

“They were the best times of my life,” she says. “It was tough, but it was also exciting.”

From this program, Yovich was cast in her professional debut, The Governor’s Family, at Belvoir in 1997, playing a young victim of gang rape. Themes of trauma have been recurring in Yovich’s stage career. “Most of my career has been about mob. And there’s always trauma in that. Always.”

Related: Barbara and the Camp Dogs: how one woman's anger became a rock show

It was through theatre, through these stories of trauma, Yovich became exposed to Australia’s true history.

“I grew up with the knowledge of the first fleet,” she says. “I was taught this other history, completely ignoring this black history. I didn’t learn about any of that through school. That was stuff I learned while working in the industry with other Aboriginal performers, other First Nation performers and writers.”

In 2017 Yovich burst on to the scene as a playwright with Barbara and the Camp Dogs, co-written with Alana Valentine. It would win a swag of Helpmann awards, and Yovich was named best female actor in a musical for her performance in it. In 2018 she premiered The Man with the Iron Neck. These plays introduced Australia to a new and compelling voice, telling contemporary Indigenous stories filled with anger, heart and humour.

The family depicted in The Man with the Iron Neck, says Yovich, “carries with it a colonial past that was negative, and damaging, and traumatic”. From this historical trauma, trauma continues, manifested in the crisis levels of suicide in Aboriginal communities.

“It follows a traumatic incident, and [asks] how does this family actually come back from something like that?” says Yovich.

Does she have an answer?

“I don’t think anyone has the answer,” she says. “But I think a good start would be the government start allowing Aboriginal people to have some kind of self-governance. There’s this kind of paternalistic view – we’re like children, and so we need to be governed.”

Her passion is palpable. “Really listening to our people and giving them self-determination – and not this fake idea of what self-determination is at this moment. The government is making decisions around our people and it’s clear for the past 230-odd years it hasn’t worked.

“And a treaty would be nice, maybe.” She laughs, but she is also resolute.

While Yovich is ardent about asking these questions on stage, it is partly because of them that she is leaving. On stage, trauma must be played out eight shows a week. The profession brings other stresses, too: constant scrutiny, financial issues, time away from family – including Yovich’s 10-year-old daughter. Stepping away from the stage, she says, is “part of growing up”.

“I think it’s time for me to move on to other things. [Theatre] wasn’t making me happy any more.”

Yovich is excited by having more time to write. “I would love the next part of my career to be more about stories about mob and stories about our issues,” she says. “Having people open their hearts and their mind to the struggles – but also the wonderful things about our culture. I don’t think people truly understand just how complex and beautiful this culture is.”

Related: City of Gold review – ambitious, raw and provocative play launches a bold new voice

There is also something different about acting for the screen. “If you’re doing something traumatic, you’re only going to feel it that one day,” she says.

When we speak, she is shooting season two of Mystery Road in Broome. “You’re going to bed when the sun goes down. You’re waking up when the sun comes up.” It’s a pace she feels at home in, “a much more holistic approach”.

It’s these ideals Yovich keeps returning to when she reflects on leaving theatre: a holistic approach to self-care, to artistic creation, to family.

Perhaps, too, more time for singing.

“That was my initial plan when I left Darwin: I just wanted to be a singer,” she says. “And I’m 42 this year so I think I can do that quite confidently now. And be OK.”

Yovich feels confident in the size of her dreams.

“I would love to travel the world just doing folk festivals,” she says. “Really simple. Not anything crazy. I just don’t see the bright lights. I know that’s not me. I don’t think it ever was.”

webTitle: Australian travellers stranded in Hong Kong after protesters shut down airport

fields.headline: Australian travellers stranded in Hong Kong after protesters shut down airport
fields.standfirst: Mass pro-democracy demonstrations have forced flight cancellations around the world
fields.trailText: Mass pro-democracy demonstrations have forced flight cancellations around the world
fields.body:
Australian travellers are facing major delays after thousands of pro-democracy protesters descended on Hong Kong’s international airport, forcing authorities to shut it down on Monday.

Operations resumed on Tuesday but further delays were expected.

Qantas cancelled three flights to Australia on Monday night. Eleven outbound services due to leave on Tuesday were also cancelled: one out of Brisbane, seven out of Melbourne and three out of Sydney.

Related: China's conduct in Hong Kong comes under cautious scrutiny on Q&A

Scott Morrison said Australians contemplating travel to Hong Kong should monitor the travel advice. He called for a peaceful resolution to the standoff.

“My view is, one, to seek to de-escalate things – to encourage the chief executive of Hong Kong to be listening carefully to what people are saying in Hong Kong and work towards a peaceful and calm resolution of what is a very, very serious issue,” the prime minister told reporters on Tuesday.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade said consular officials from the consulate general in Hong Kong and Macau were at the airport on Monday to help Australian tourists leave it safely.

A video circulating online shows an Australian man stranded at the airport complaining about protesters.

Two Virgin Australia flights due to leave Australia on Monday night were also cancelled.

Other Australian travellers stuck in Hong Kong described chaotic scenes.

“Quite eye-opening to arrive from Paris into a sea of protests and find my onward flight to Sydney no longer existed,” one, Paul Dennett, tweeted on Monday.

Anyone planning to travel between Australia and Hong Kong has been urged to check with their airline.

The Australian government’s Smartraveller website continued to warn people to exercise a high degree of caution while in Hong Kong.

“Flash mob protests and random attacks on protesters have become less predictable and are expected to continue,” it warned.

“Tourist and residential areas have been affected. There is a high risk of violent confrontation between protesters and police, or criminally linked individuals.”

webTitle: Judge who said borrowers could cut down on steak and shiraz labelled 'out of touch'

fields.headline: Judge who said borrowers could cut down on steak and shiraz labelled 'out of touch'
fields.standfirst: Consumer advocates criticise decision dismissing legal action against Westpac, which had been accused of 250,000 cases of irresponsible lending
fields.trailText: Consumer advocates criticise decision dismissing legal action against Westpac, which had been accused of 250,000 cases of irresponsible lending
fields.body:
A judge who said borrowers could cut down on wagyu beef and “the finest shiraz” to make their home loan payments is out of touch with reality, consumer advocates say.

The Consumer Action Law Centre and the Financial Rights Legal Centre (FRLC) said the remarks, made by federal court judge Nye Perram, showed the law needed to be changed to force banks to properly consider the financial circumstances of borrowers.

On Tuesday, Perram dismissed legal action the corporate regulator brought against Westpac in which it accused the bank of lending irresponsibly more than 250,000 times by using a controversial benchmark to decide whether to make home loans instead of working out whether each customer could afford to repay the money.

Use of the benchmark, called the household expenditure measure or Hem, to make lending decisions was heavily criticised during last year’s banking royal commission on the grounds it underestimates living expenses.

But the federal court ruling allows Westpac, and other lenders, to continue to use the measure.

Related: Kenneth Hayne says trust in politics and institutions 'damaged or destroyed'

Asic filed its lawsuit against Westpac in 2017 as part of a crackdown on the lax lending standards of Australian banks, who were at the time pumping money into the country’s housing boom.

It said Westpac had failed to meet responsible lending standards between 2011 and 2014 by using the Hem instead of living expenses declared by customers.

But in his judgment Perram said Westpac “did have regard to these declared living expenses”.

The judge also said while the law required lenders to ask borrowers about their financial situation, he did not accept this had the “consequence that the credit provider must use the consumer’s declared living expenses in doing so”.

He played down the importance of the Hem, saying by the end of the trial “it had become clear that the evidence concerning the Hem benchmark was relevant only to one minor issue”.

And the customer’s actual expenses were only relevant if they “simply cannot be forgone or reduced beyond a certain point”, he said.

“I may eat Wagyu beef every day, washed down with the finest shiraz but, if I really want my new home, I can make do on much more modest fare.”

Calc chief executive Gerard Brody said: “To suggest that borrowers ditch wagyu steaks and shiraz for cheaper food really is out of touch with the realities faced by most Australians.”

“The rules and procedures applied by Westpac could equally have approved borrowers who have significant medical expenses, or additional education and recreational expenses for a child with a disability.

“People who work long hours may eat out and/or have high child care costs as a necessary corollary of being able to keep the job they need to be able to afford their mortgage in the first place.”

FRLC chief executive Karen Cox said the decision was “incredibly disappointing”.

“The decision suggests that banks do not have to have regard to people’s actual expenses when they lend – which in turn will allow lenders to continue to extend unsustainable loans which set people up to fail.”

Asic will now have to pay the costs of a case both sides thought was settled last year.

In September Westpac agreed to pay Asic $35m, which would have been the largest civil penalty levied under credit laws, and admit to failing to use declared expenses and failing to take into account the higher repayments due after interest-free periods expired on some loans.

But, in a highly unusual move, Perram refused to approve the deal.

Asic commissioner Sean Hughes said the regulator, which has 28 days to lodge an appeal, was “reviewing the judgment carefully”.

He said Asic took action against Westpac as a test case.

“As a regulator, it is our role to test the law,” he said.

“The obligation to assess applications builds on the obligation on banks to make inquiries about a borrower’s financial circumstances and capacity to service a loan and to verify the information that borrowers give banks.”

Westpac has been approached for comment.

webTitle: NRL revolutionary Robbie Farah was ahead of his time | Nick Tedeschi

fields.headline: NRL revolutionary Robbie Farah was ahead of his time
fields.standfirst: There is little question that Farah is the greatest player in the 20-year history of the Wests Tigers
fields.trailText: There is little question that Farah is the greatest player in the 20-year history of the Wests Tigers
fields.body:
Maybe it was just never meant to be. And it could have been worse. It could have ended on that lonely Sunday afternoon atop the Leichhardt scoreboard, sweating in a suit, tie askew, drinking a tinny of beer, filled with nothing but bitterness and anger.

The Tigers were beaten 52-10, their finals hopes finished by Canberra. Robbie Farah wasn’t playing. He had fallen out with coach Jason Taylor and was dropped to reserve grade despite playing State of Origin that year.

The scene was poetic but the undercurrent was poisonous. It wasn’t a sincere goodbye. It was a genuine middle finger. That was the Tigers finale Farah seemed destined to live with.

Related: Valentine Holmes impresses on NFL debut for New York Jets

His NRL finale seemed even more bleak. After shifting to South Sydney in 2017, he found himself stuck behind Damien Cook and managed just two top grade appearances for the club in 2018. Playing NSW Cup at North Sydney Oval and Henson Park might be a spectacle for the purists but it looked an undignified farewell for arguably the best hooker not named Cameron Smith to don a boot this century.

He was a Tiger, not a Bear. And he, mercifully, would be a Tiger again, returned to his rightful home midway through the 2018 season, a combination of fortune and fairytale that allowed Farah an encore at Leichhardt.

It was a return of a prodigal son moment but it was also a genuine catharsis for both a club that was struggling with its identity and a club legend renowned for his ability to carry resentment as well as he could carry the club during lean years and good.

Farah’s return did not disappoint. The Tigers did not play finals football in 2018 and are teetering on the precipice this year but the club is in a much better spot. They have made peace with Farah and fellow club legend Benji Marshall. They found a coach who will work. They started priding themselves on stability, grit and hard work.

The club today is very much a reflection of Farah the player. After years in the wilderness, happy to play shootout footy and churn through coaches and find trouble with bad signings, the Tigers seem to finally be recognising what they had at their disposal all along.

There is little question that Farah is the greatest player in the 20-year history of the Wests Tigers. Marshall may have been more beloved but Farah, having debuted in 2003, was both the best and most consistent performer to don the black, orange and white.

Stylistically, Farah was ahead of his time, a revolutionary who was mightily unlucky to have his career run parallel to Smith, arguably the greatest to ever play the game. Early in his career, Farah had underrated speed and very much resembled a player like Cook. That speed set him apart from most of his contemporaries early but it was his creativity that became his trademark.

His work on the tryline in particular stood out in the early 2000s for its transcendence. His deft grubber kicks from dummy half and his flat cut-out passes just were not seen at the time. He helped not only revolutionise the No 9 jersey but spawn, with Smith, the next great generation of hookers.

His brilliance in attack though should not take away from his sheer toughness in defence. For most of his career he played 80 minutes, in the middle, doing a ton of tackling. He was a serious man who played hard and played tough, as relentless with his tongue and his thinking as he was with his hitting and courage. In that sense, he was the modern-day Benny Elias, blood and brilliance, hard noses and soft passes.

He was integral to the Tigers’ only – and most unlikely – premiership and in their only great era, Farah was at his peak. He was a regular on a Blues team that got whipped regularly but he gave everything in 16 games, winning the Brad Fittler medal in 2012. Eight times he wore the green and gold and twice beat out Cameron Smith for Dally M hooker of the year honours.

It was his unforgiving nature though that will most be remembered. He was hard to like at times but he had earned the respect of everyone in the game a long time ago and never lost it.

To steal a quote from the incomparable Jimmy McNulty, Farah “asked no quarter and none was given … he brooked no authority, he did what he wanted to do and he said what he wanted to say”.

Farah looks to have again had his farewell dictated to him. A leg fracture picked up against Canterbury at ANZ on Saturday night means he is unlikely to play again. He will miss out on the fairytale finale again. This time though, he will be much more at peace with it.
